awd_titl_txt: CHS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Intelligent Context-Aware Peer-to-Peer Transaction Brokering
awd_abstract_narration:
Peer-to-peer exchange is transforming economic activity, through unprecedented integration of social and practical action.  This project will produce a full-scale implementation of a more efficient model of it that can be emulated across many social and economic domains.  Peer-to-peer exchange is the direct exchange of goods and services by citizens, mediated by a brokering entity, typically embodied as an information system.  It is an emerging paradigm that integrates economic and social interaction, creating many possibilities for innovation.  It encompasses diverse services such as ride sharing, everyday tasks, textbook sharing, accommodation sharing , car sharing , sharing parking, local food exchange, sharing household items, exchanging home-cooked meals, sharing workspace and expertise, timebanking, and municipal development . Many of these applications make use of otherwise wasted resources such as parked cars, empty bedrooms, and idle time, increasing the efficiency and sustainability of economic activity. Their number and size have mushroomed; they are now referred to collectively as the "collaborative economy."
 
Many peer-to-peer exchanges involve sharing goods and services "just in time," that is, sharing precisely when someone needs something and someone else is prepared to provide it.  Thus, one key to the success of peer-to-peer exchanges is close coordination of providers/offerers and recipients/requesters.  In a recent NSF project, members of the current research team investigated mobile timebanking using smartphone clients, a system in which members of a community can volunteer specific hours of labor they are well prepared to perform, in exchange for hours of labor from other community members, counting each hour equally.  A key challenge was a lack of coordination in arranging "just in time" service exchanges. 
 
This new research will investigate computational approaches to coordinating collaborative interactions mediated by contextual intelligence.  Also studied will be what sorts of user, task, and interaction information facilitate effective "just in time" service exchanges, and how users appropriate and experience these exchanges.  A large field trial will investigate the adoption, usability, and utilization of context-aware peer-to-peer transaction brokering and will provide early reports of results and help a variety of organizations implement techniques that have been shown to work.
 
The research will extend current understanding of motivations for engaging in helpful economic transactions, the formation of social connections through such transactions, and of how to enhance subjective wellbeing by fostering practical helping behaviors through context-aware technology.  A prime objective is to identify strategies for contextually facilitated peer-to-peer exchange that can energize economic exchange activity, and support new kinds of exchange, while enhancing social consequences and concomitants of exchange interactions.

por.por_cntn:
Peer-to-peer exchange is the direct exchange of goods and services by citizens, mediated by a brokering entity, typically embodied as an information system. It is an emerging paradigm that integrates economic and social interaction, creating many possibilities for innovation. It encompasses diverse services such as ride sharing, everyday tasks, textbook sharing, accommodation sharing, car sharing, sharing parking, local food exchange, sharing household items, exchanging home-cooked meals, sharing workspace and expertise, timebanking, and municipal development.

With our collaborators from Carnegie-Mellon University and the Palo Alto Research Center, we investigated context-awareness in peer-to-peer exchange. We worked with the hOurWorld timebank group, who helped us to access experienced participants. We developed a model of context-aware service exchange, and embodied it in a mobile application to support ride sharing. We found that experienced participants in peer-to-peer exchange were able to see the value of context-awareness, that is, of effective "just in time" service exchanges in which they could know that potential partners would be interested in transacting with them (based on abilities, preferences, needs, and availability). Participants expressed interest in having context-awareness incorporated into timebanking exchange (Jung et al. 2016).

We carried out two field trials in which users were able to interact with a context-aware mobile system and arrange and respond to proposed interactions, informed by context - NeighborGenie.  People were able to grasp these interactions and carry them out with little or training.  Participants quickly developed an articulated sense of how to use the context-awareness capabilities to enhance their own user experience, particularly with respect to their own convenience in terms of time and location (Doryab, et al, 2017).

Our second study showed that users also reported feeling emotionally closer to partners they interacted with when they had shared/received information about that person's location and preferences, and that context-aware interactions - which depend on being in the same place at the same time - evoked sense of community in participants (Chen et al., 2019b).

We also investigated a lightweight context-awareness model that emphasized coproduction of social goods instead of currency- or barter-based exchange (Carroll et al, 2016). Our system supported everyday activities that a person could do alone or together with another person. Our system - WithShare - supported finding partners for these activities. We found that although there were inhibitions about joining a partner one did not already know, participants were positive about the experience, and reported subsequent positive experiences of re-encountering a previously unknown other. In this sense, the system supported initial formation of social ties that were capable of developing further (Chen et al, 2019b).

The WithShare study motivated us to focus more attention on social scaffolding for peer-to-peer interactions. We investigated the MeetUp platform, as used to mediate a wide range of social activities. We focused on the role distinctions that enable effective mangement of MeetUp groups, including rewarding social coproduction (Chen et al, 2019a).

Works Cited

Carroll et al. 2016. In search of co-production: Smart services as reciprocal. IEEE Computer. 49 (7), 26. 

Chen et al. 2019a. Withshare: A Mobile Application to Support Community Coproduction Activities. International Journal of Mobile Human-Computer Interaction.

Chen et al. 2019b. Context-aware Coproduction: Implications for Recommendation Algorithms. iConference. 

Chen et al. 2019c. Beyond Leaders and Followers: Understanding Participation Dynamics in Event-based Social Networks. International Journal and Human-Computer Interaction. 

Doryab et al. 2017. If it’s convenient: Leveraging Context in peer-to-peer service transaction recommendations. Proceedings of the ACM on Interactive, Mobile, Wearable and Ubiquitous Technologies (IMWUT). 1 (3), 

Jung et al. 2016. `MASTerful' Matchmaking in Service Transactions: Inferred Abilities, Needs and Interests versus Activity Histories. 34th Annual ACM Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems (CHI’16).
